p: In the United States, beginning in the early 1900s, annual epidemics of poliomyelitis occurred with regularity until the introduction of the polio vaccine in 1955. In one such outbreak in 1921, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, a former President of the United States, to which a highway was named in his honor in Trinidad, was infected with the virus in his 14 th year, emphasizing that white elites could be affected. His family recorded: “Below his waist, he cannot move at all. His legs have to be moved often as they ache when long in one position.”[ 13] His subsequent contributions to polio included the creation of a National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis (now known as the March of Dimes) which raised money for the rehabilitation of victims of paralytic polio and was also instrumental in funding the development of the polio vaccine.
